.larger[.hand[How would you describe a categorical variable?]]

---

class: middle, center 

.larger[In `R`...]

categorical variables can have either `character` *or* `factor` data types

--

`factor` -- structured & fixed number of levels / options

--

`character` -- unstructured & variable number of levels

.rhubarb[.huge[Opinionated Plotting]]

---


.larger[Why should I use ggplot2?]

.pull-left[
**Pros** 

- Simple to create complex plots

- Programmatic interface

- Minimal changes to change visualization types 

- Default customizations are desirable
]

.pull-right[
![](images/ggplot_logo.png)

**Cons** 

- New syntax to learn! 
]


---

.pull-left[
.larger[`ggplot()`]

- Same syntax for every plot
- Change `geom`etric object for different plots
]

--

.pull-right[
.larger["base" R]

Different functions for different types of plots

- Scatterplot: `plot()`
- Boxplot: `boxplot()`
- Histogram: `hist()` 
- Density plot: `density()`
- Bar plot: `barplot()`
]
